qas.question: Who was incorrctly quoted in saying "The Battle of Waterloo was won on the playing-fields of Eton"?
During what years was the Duke of Wellington at Eton?
What "stuff" won Waterloo, according to Wellington?

answers.text: the manly character induced by games and sport

qas.question: What years did Nevill attend Eton?
For what years did Sir William Fraser attend Eton?
Who was the Duke of Wellington?
In what year was Charles de Montalembert made a Duke?
In what year was Edward Creasy made a Sir?

context: The <a0_0>Duke of Wellington<a0_0/> is often incorrectly quoted as saying that "The Battle of Waterloo was won on the playing-fields of Eton". Wellington was at Eton from <a1_0><b3_0><b4_0><b7_0>1781<b7_0/> to <b6_0>1784<b6_0/><b4_0/><b3_0/><a1_0/> and was to send his sons there. According to Nevill (citing the historian Sir <b5_0>Edward Creasy<b5_0/>), what Wellington said, while passing an Eton cricket match many decades later, was, "There grows the stuff that won Waterloo", a remark Nevill construes as a reference to "<a2_0>the manly character induced by games and sport<a2_0/>" amongst English youth generally, not a comment about Eton specifically. In 1889, Sir William Fraser conflated this uncorroborated remark with the one attributed to him by Count Charles de Montalembert's "C'est ici qu'a été gagné la bataille de Waterloo" ("It is here that the Battle of Waterloo was won.")
